Thus Nathanael can be called "a TRUE Israelite in whom there is no guile" (1:47) and Jesus is hailed as "king of Israel" (1:49), a title whose entirely positive connotations contrast with "king of the Jews," which has a negative and sarcastic ring on the lips of Romans (e.g., 19:3).  I don't think you can match numbers on people that see religious benefit for themselves versus those that don't. Most people hold some kind of religious beliefs and they presumably believe that they are better off with their beliefs than without them. A crucial question is how you quantify "betterness". In the Darwinistic sense of betterness, it appears that religion (or at least the acceptance of religion) has the upper hand. If it were "better" to disbelieve religion, then presumably we would be born with an aversion to religion. Obviously that aversion is not present.

1st Century Jerusalem Burial Cave Reveals: Names, Testimonies of First Christians
 
 The first century catacomb, uncovered by archaeologist P. Bagatti on the Mount of Olives, contains inscriptions clearly indicating its use, "by the very first Christians in Jerusalem."
 
 An inscription, found on a first century coffin bearing the sign of the cross, reads: "Shimon Bar Yonah" = "Simon [Peter] son of Jonah". 
 
 The catacombs were found and excavated primarily by two well-known archaeologists, but their findings were later read and verified by other scholars such as Yigael Yadin, J. T. Milik and J. Finegan. Both archaeologists found evidence clearly dating the two catacombs to the first century AD, with the later finding coins minted by Governor Varius Gratus at the turn of the millenium (up to 15/16 AD). Evidence in both catacombs indicated their use for burial until the middle part of the first century AD, several years before the New Testament was written.  
 
 As Claremont-Ganneau further investigated the tomb, he found inscriptions, including the names of "Eleazar"(="Lazarus"), "Martha" and "Mary" on three different coffins.  
 
 Bagatti also found evidence which clearly indicated that the tomb was in use in the early part of the first century AD. Inside, the sign of the cross was found on numerous first-century coffins.
 
 He found dozens of inscribed ossuaries, which included the names Jairus, Jonathan, Joseph, Judah, Matthias, Menahem, Salome, Simon, and Zechariah. In addition, he found one ossuary with crosses and the unusual name "Shappira" - which is a unique name not found in any other first-century writtings except for the Book of Acts (5:1). 
 
 Photographs in the link below
 
 http://www.leaderu.com/theology/burialcave.html
 
 Now, a 2nd Article:
 
 Need something etched in stone confirming Jesus before 70 A.D.?  
 
 "This catacomb on the Mount of Olives belonged apparently to one of the earliest families which joined the new religion of Christianity. In this group of sarcophagi, some of which have the Christian symbol and some have not, we are, so to speak, [witnessing the] actual unfolding of Christianity. Personally, I think that many of the Hebrew-speaking people whose remains are contained in these ossuaries were among the first followers of Christ.... The appearance of Christianity at the very gates of Jerusalem is, in my opinion, extraordinary and unprecedented. Somehow the new [Christian] doctrine must have made its way into the Jewish system.... The association of the sign of the cross with (the name of Jesus) written in Hebrew alone constitutes a valuable fact." 
 
 "What gives additional value to these short inscriptions is that they furnish a whole series of names found in the Gospels, in their popular and local Syro-Chaldaic forms. The presence of the names of Jesus and Martha, of which we only knew historically that it was the feminine form of the Aramaic, would alone be sufficient to make this collection important from an exegetic point of view. By a singular coincidence, which from the first struck me forcibly, these inscriptions, found close to the Bethany road, and very near the site of the village, contain nearly all the names of the personages in the Gospel scenes which belonged to the place: Eleazar (Lazarus), Simon, Martha ... a host of other coincidences occur at the sight of all these most evangelical names." 
 
 Italian scholar P. Bagatti discovered another catacomb holding 100 ossuaries on the western side of the Mount of Olives. Coins that were minted by Governor Varius Gratus (A.D. 16) showed that these tombs were used for burial of Christians before A.D. 70. The name of Jesus was found on ossuaries of priests found in the catacomb, indicating they were probably followers of Jesus. Many of the ossuaries included other names, such as Jarius, Jonathan, Joseph, Judah, Matthias, Menahem, Salome, Simon, and Zechariah. 
 
 The name of Jesus was found on ossuaries of priests found in the catacomb, indicating they were probably followers of Jesus. Many of the ossuaries included other names, such as Jarius, Jonathan, Joseph, Judah, Matthias, Menahem, Salome, Simon, and Zechariah. 
 
 There was one ossuary which contained the inscription, "Iota, Chi and Beta," which reads "Jesus Christ, the Redeemer."  
 
 Ossuary containing an inscription, "[To] Jesus, "the Lord." Attests to the Christians' acknowledgement of Jesus Christ as God within 10 years of the death/resurrection of Jesus. (American Journal of Archaeology)

If it were "better" to disbelieve religion, then presumably we would be born with an aversion to religion. Obviously that aversion is not present.

(sadly, they are suffering because of osama's beliefs, and then george bush's beliefs, not because of their own)

there are millions of people that are immersed in the blissful ignorance that religion offers. and there are millions of people that are discriminated against, oppressed, and killed, because of the dogma that religion offers. neither of these effects are beneficial in the least.

 You didn't respond to my post. If you want to argue, please quote me, and address what I say.

There's no way to run the experiment without religion in the cases you mention, therefore it is unclear what would have happened. You said that "more likely we'd all be better off". I don't see that being supported, especially the "all" part.

 i showed exactly how the overall net effect of removing all religion would be positive. unless you can show otherwise, then you are the one whose position needs support
 
 
What? Blissful ignorance is not beneficial in the least? How do you define beneficial? That which is beneficial according to unkerpaulie? 
 Is there nobody benefiting from the oppression and killing? Surely, somebody on earth is benefiting. The guy selling bullets, perhaps.

 the key point is "overall net result". you are acheiving nothing by trying to identify minorities that are benefiting. beneficial is defined on dictionary.com as producing or promoting a favorable result; advantageous. in the context of my quote, beneficial implies the overall net result.
 
 
You didn't respond to my post. If you want to argue, please quote me, and address what I say.

Jesus just left Chicago and he's bound for New Orleans. Working from one end to the other...and all points in-between.

i showed exactly how the overall net effect of removing all religion would be positive. unless you can show otherwise, then you are the one whose position needs support

 No, you most certainly did not show the overall net effect of removing all religion would be positive. There is no way to run the experiment with all religion absent. You are merely guessing that it would be "better". 
 
 I have no burden to support my position, since you haven't challenged it. If you want to challenge me, please provide a direct quote, and state your objection.
 
 
 
the key point is "overall net result". you are acheiving nothing by trying to identify minorities that are benefiting. 

 Why don't you address what I've already said?
 
You said that "more likely we'd all be better off". I don't see that being supported, especially the "all" part. 

 If one person benefits, then your contention is wrong: "more likely that we'd all be better off." I asked you if you were backpedaling and you said "no backpedaling at all". Make up your mind. Either support the notion that more likely we'd all be better off or concede.
 
beneficial is defined on dictionary.com as producing or promoting a favorable result; advantageous. in the context of my quote, beneficial implies the overall net result. 

 No. You said "more likely we'd all be better off". Are you conceding?
 Anyway, this is hardly a quantification. Favorable in what way? Who gets to decide what is favorable and what is not favorable? Is unkerpaulie the final arbiter? I suggested "beneficial" could be Darwinistic beneficiality, but you failed to respond to that suggestion.
 
look carefully at the structure of post #33. you'll see that i quoted you and addressed what you said. i shouldnt have to point this out, but you apparently missed it

 Go back and look at #33 and you will see that you did not address each of my points. Please note at no time did I object to the notion that many people are victimized in the name of religion. Therefore, you needn't go on about this. Break up my post into points and address each one.

for toby's sake, lets do this again
 
Are you backpedaling on the opinion that we would all be better off?

Most people hold some kind of religious beliefs and they presumably believe that they are better off with their beliefs than without them.

A crucial question is how you quantify "betterness".

 since you have no way to quantify betterness, how can you possibly judge the validity of my position? is betterness defined as whatever toby calls betterness?
 
In the Darwinistic sense of betterness, it appears that religion (or at least the acceptance of religion) has the upper hand.

 if you are speaking of the acceptance of religion (in the sense that religion is allowed freedom to run its course) then religious acceptance has no advantage over atheistic acceptance, since it too is equally allowed to run its course. if you are speaking about the number of religious people in the world, you are in no position to assume that because of religion's popularity, that means that religion is an advantage. poverty is more widespread than wealth. i suppose by your logic poverty has the upper hand. your logic is flawed. commonality has absolutely nothing to do with advantageousness
 
 
If it were "better" to disbelieve religion, then presumably we would be born with an aversion to religion. Obviously that aversion is not present.

 obviously? again with the baseless assumptions. what proof can you provide that anyone is born with an inclination towards religion? please refrain from thoughtless assumptions unless you can back it up with some facts

no i am not. i maintain my position. your assumption that i am backpedalling is baseless

 I'm not assuming that you are backpedaling. Your insinuation that I assume that you are backpedaling is fallacious. I'm trying to get you to either defend your initial position that we'd likely all be better off (which you seemingly don't even recognize) or abandon it. Nevertheless if I had made the assumption that you were backpedaling it would hardly be baseless, given your repeated refusal to even recognize that you said: "more likely we'd all be better off".
 For the third time, please address: 
 
You said that "more likely we'd all be better off". I don't see that being supported, especially the "all" part. 

 If one person benefits, then your contention is wrong: "more likely that we'd all be better off." I asked you if you were backpedaling and you said "no backpedaling at all". Make up your mind. Either support the notion that more likely we'd all be better off or concede.

 I searched around for a while and found http://vanallens.com/exchristian/worldreligions.html which cites as the 
 Data source: Encyclopædia Britannica Book of the Year 1996. Apparently approximately 81% of the world's population ascribes to belonging to some religion, while 19% does not. I found no source that had over 22% as non-religious, much less over 50%.
 Presumably these 81% (78% or whatever) see religious benefit for themselves. 
 
 Nevertheless, you are the hook to show that without religion that "more likely we'd all be better off". That's "we'd all" not "most us of would".

 You are presenting a fallacious argument. I said: 
 
 ...they presumably believe that they are better off with their beliefs than without them

 I didn't say that they are better off; I said presumably they believe they are better off. I still don't know whether they are "better" off or not. You have been unable to quantify "betterness", therefore I suspect your claim that we'd likely all be better off is vacuous.
 
 
 since you have no way to quantify betterness, how can you possibly judge the validity of my position? is betterness defined as whatever toby calls betterness? 

 It was your position that we'd most likely all be "better" off. I have asked repeatedly for a quantification of "betterness", and you apparently have none. Your position seems vacuous. Your position might as well be we'd most likely all be "worse" off.
 
 
 if you are speaking of the acceptance of religion (in the sense that religion is allowed freedom to run its course) then religious acceptance has no advantage over atheistic acceptance, since it too is equally allowed to run its course. 

 The ability to accept the game of day (either religion or atheism) is advantageous. One is more likely to mate if one can play along with whatever game is present. If one is predisposed toward any definitive belief, one is more liable to find himself dead or cast out. 
 
 
 if you are speaking about the number of religious people in the world, you are in no position to assume that because of religion's popularity, that means that religion is an advantage. poverty is more widespread than wealth. i suppose by your logic poverty has the upper hand. your logic is flawed. commonality has absolutely nothing to do with advantageousness

 obviously? again with the baseless assumptions. what proof can you provide that anyone is born with an inclination towards religion? please refrain from thoughtless assumptions unless you can back it up with some facts

 Furthermore, what you think is thoughtless is of no account. You seem to be trying to poison my well.

there are millions of people that are immersed in the blissful ignorance that religion offers.

Billsco:
 
 In reference to the comments that evangelicals would be considered anti semitic due to the new testament emphasis on the jewish responsibility for the death of jesus (I hope I characterized what I read correctly):
 
 Evangelicals truly believe that all humans, each individual is responsible for the crucifixion of jesus. There is nothing anti-semitic about christians any more than buddhists etc. All anti semitism comes from hatred the very thing that put jesus on the cross. To hate jews or anyone else is not a christian doctrine or dogma. Christianity is meant to be marked by love "By this all men will know you are my disciples, that you love one another" The story of the good samaritan, the parable of the prodigal etc.
 
 If a christian is fomenting hatred towards ANYONE of any race, religion, creed, origin etc, then he should seriously look at what he truly believes about Jesus, because I guarantee that he is not living the life Christ would have wanted.
 
 EF

How do Evangelicals justify their abhorrent behavior?

 
 I think you have cart and horse the wrong way round. A culture's (or subculture's) sociopolitical outlook shapes its religious views and practice, not vice versa. People with abhorrent (to a liberal) sociopolitical views - in particular, people with a strong desire to keep other groups 'in their place' - find the kind of evangelical christianity you describe fits them like a glove.

For the third time, please address: 
 
You said that "more likely we'd all be better off". I don't see that being supported, especially the "all" part. 

 If one person benefits, then your contention is wrong: "more likely that we'd all be better off." I asked you if you were backpedaling and you said "no backpedaling at all". Make up your mind. Either support the notion that more likely we'd all be better off or concede. 

 again, concede to what? what assertion have you made that is there to concede to? my position starts off with the phrase "more likely". something that is considered more likely is not considered a guaranteed definite. if in the case of a world without religion, there were people that were worse of rather than better off, it still would not make the odds of "more likely" any different. for example, if there are 10 red marbles and 2 blue marbles in a bag, it is considered "more likely" that i will pull a red marble first. if i pull a blue marble out of the bag first, it doesnt make the likeliness of pulling a red marble first anydifferent. hence the phrase "more likely". 
 
 furthermore, you have no way of measuring if "all" the people in the world would be better off or not, regardless of how "better off" is defined, because you havent seen a world without religion. my position stands, and you have yet to disprove it

I searched around for a while and found http://vanallens.com/exchristian/worldreligions.html which cites as the 
 Data source: Encyclopædia Britannica Book of the Year 1996. Apparently approximately 81% of the world's population ascribes to belonging to some religion, while 19% does not. I found no source that had over 22% as non-religious, much less over 50%.
 Presumably these 81% (78% or whatever) see religious benefit for themselves. 

 again, totally baseless presumption. apparently you are of the opinion that if the majority of people in the world are in a particular state, that means that that is the more beneficial state. i have already demonstrated to you that your logic is flawed, but you still insist repeating the same flawed logic
 
 let me make myself clear again: the majority of people being in a particular state does not make that state more benficial. 
 
 
I didn't say that they are better off; I said presumably they believe they are better off. I still don't know whether they are "better" off or not. You have been unable to quantify "betterness", therefore I suspect your claim that we'd likely all be better off is vacuous.

 yes. you made a PRESUMPTION. and your presumption is baseless. you cannot presume that people believe anything and offer it as support for any type of argument. a presumption is imaginary, and not substantial as evidence. i am under no obligation to entertain your baseless presumptions
 
 
It was your position that we'd most likely all be "better" off. I have asked repeatedly for a quantification of "betterness", and you apparently have none. Your position seems vacuous. Your position might as well be we'd most likely all be "worse" off.

 i have provided the dictionary definition of betterness. furthermore, you have failed to provide any evidence showing that in a world without religion everyone would NOT be better off. if you cannot quantify betterness yourself, then you have no basis by which to challenge my statement
 
 
The ability to accept the game of day (either religion or atheism) is advantageous. One is more likely to mate if one can play along with whatever game is present. If one is predisposed toward any definitive belief, one is more liable to find himself dead or cast out. 

 flawed logic. the ability to rise beyond mediocrity is advantageous as well. so is the ability to perform beyond average. by simply subscribing to whatever is the norm has absolutely no correlation to survivability. some cases it is advantageous to follow the crowd. in some cases it is detrimental. your generalization is fallacious and poorly thought out
 
 
Commonality has absolutely nothing to do with advantageousness? Prove it.

 i would replace the phrase "has absolutely nothing to do with" with "is not directly related to". a partial withdrawal
 
 
There seems to be a great drive to conform. If conformance were not advantageous, why would the drive exist?
 
 Yes, poverty (the acceptance of poverty) does seem to have had the upper hand. Some people kill themselves rather than be poor, but most seem to accept poverty.
 Africans accepted slavery and were able to reproduce. 

 utter garbage. first of all, the majority of africans were not slaves, so your analogy is flawed. second, africans never "accepted" slavery. there was no drive to become a slave where the africans were concerned. third, most slaves were not permitted to reproduce, or were under severe reproduction controls. it was only after the abolition of slavery that the black population outside of africa flourished. facts please. your presumptions are really annoying to deal with. with every post you make, your educational void is displayed even more
 
 
I didn't say that anyone is born with an inclination towards religion. Your attempt to change my words is fallacious.
 Furthermore, what you think is thoughtless is of no account. You seem to be trying to poison my well. 
 You already admitted:
there are millions of people that are immersed in the blissful ignorance that religion offers. 

 That a great many people are religious is evidence that Darwin is allowing it. On the other hand, Darwin is not allowing many people to drink copious amounts of chlorine bleach.

 you said 
 
If it were "better" to disbelieve religion, then presumably we would be born with an aversion to religion. Obviously that aversion is not present.

 where do you come up with these presumptions? being born without an aversion to religion implies nothing about whether accepting religion is "better" or not. obviously, an aversion to atheism is not present either, so your point is moot

my position starts off with the phrase "more likely". something that is considered more likely is not considered a guaranteed definite. if in the case of a world without religion, there were people that were worse of rather than better off, it still would not make the odds of "more likely" any different. for example, if there are 10 red marbles and 2 blue marbles in a bag, it is considered "more likely" that i will pull a red marble first. if i pull a blue marble out of the bag first, it doesnt make the likeliness of pulling a red marble first anydifferent. hence the phrase "more likely". 
 
 furthermore, you have no way of measuring if "all" the people in the world would be better off or not, regardless of how "better off" is defined, because you havent seen a world without religion. my position stands, and you have yet to disprove it

 Without a quantification of betterness, your position is vacuous. It might just as well be more likely we'd all be worse off. I don't need to disprove it; the burden of proof is on you. At this time, your claim is completely meaningless, and there would be no way to disprove it even if I wanted to. 
 Your statement that I haven't seen a world without religion goes equally well for you. I already said this in my post #36: 
 
 There's no way to run the experiment without religion in the cases you mention, therefore it is unclear what would have happened. 

 However, once again the burden is not on me, but on you. You need to demonstrate that more likely we'd all be better off. You seem to be undermining any chance you would have had in doing that.
 
 i have provided the dictionary definition of betterness. furthermore, you have failed to provide any evidence showing that in a world without religion everyone would NOT be better off. if you cannot quantify betterness yourself, then you have no basis by which to challenge my statement

 The dictionary definition is not a quantification and does not allow you to demonstrate that more likely we'd all be better off. I don't need provide evidence showing anything. The burden of proof is on you as the claimant. At this time, your claim is completely meaningless, and there would be no way to disprove it even if I wanted to. It is not my job to quantify betterness with respect to your claim. You have made a claim; you need to define the terms of your claim. If you cannot define the terms, then your position is vacuous. 
 
 All the rest of your post is either tangential to the main issue and/or cannot be reasonably be addressed without quantifying "betterness". It has turned into a quagmire. If you want more satisfaction on any of these points, I'd like to table them until you specify what "betterness" is, or resurrect them on a different forum. For example, if you want to debate the Darwinistic betterrness of the acceptance of slavery, please start a new thread (on the Creation vs. Evolution forum).
